Grammar: The Causative
I've done my nails
study abroad programme
She [k]hasn't had[/k] her hair cut for a long time.
Julia
Yes, but the main thing I'm worried about is the [k]wedding dress[/k]. The people at the shop said it would take a long time to alter in the way I want it.
Sarah
I will fix it
[k]I will have my nails done[/k]

When we want to say that we organised someone else to do something we use the causative (have / get something done). The causative is often used when the person performing the action is unknown or unimportant.
orientation meeting
Which important life event would you like to experience next? Why?
We know who performed the action.
I'm going to paint the house
Are you going to have a religious ceremony or a civil ceremony?
am getting my eyes tested
I remember that as a child I would spend hours dreaming about my wedding. Right now I'm dreaming about the [k]honeymoon[/k], when it will all be over!
[k]I had the gardening done[/k]
[k]I have my hair done[/k]
Thanks! I'm so busy at the moment, preparing for the [k]wedding[/k]!
[k]I've had my nails done[k]
David
What type of accommodation do you prefer?
I'm afraid not, but we have recommended a [k]host family[/k] for you.
No, it's actually for the [k]academic year [/k].
And what about accommodation, did I get into the [k]halls of residence[/k]?
That's not so bad. I might not make as many friends, but at least I'll be immersed in the culture. Also, my fluency and pronunciation will improve, which is my main reason for going.
exchange programme

I'm having my hair cut at lunchtime.
I got the things delivered to my work address.
internship
[k]The house will be painted[/k]
Great, I'm so happy! Is it for a [k]semester[/k]?
Can I apply to do a course for the academic year or only for one semester?
I got my eyes tested the other day.
[k]Are you getting[/k] the party food delivered this year?
I painted my house at the weekend.
[k]I'm having my hair done[/k]
[k]I got the gardening did[/k]
halls of residence
[k]I'm going to painting the house[/k]
I hear you and Mark are [k]getting married[/k]! Congratulations!
Don't worry! You're going to have the wedding of your dreams!
Select the words in the correct order.
host family
I [k]got my eyes tested[/k] last weekend.
[k]I would get it fixed[/k]

I got my eyes tested...
I had my eyes tested...
We don't generally say who performed the action with causative sentences, but if we want to, we can add 'by + the doer of the action'.
[k]I'm getting my car cleaned[/k]
I did the gardening
You are getting
We can make causative sentences negative or questions by changing the form of have or get in the sentence:
rings
Traditionally rings have been a symbol of union.
Active phrase
wedding dress
I got the things delivered to my work address.
The person in bold did not perform the action.
doesn't have
Are the halls of residence located within walking distance of the school?
Claudia designed her own wedding dress.
I do my hair
wedding
accommodation
Who is in charge of finding a host family?
[k]I will get it fixed[/k]
To form the causative we use have / get + object + Past Participle form of the main verb. The tense is shown by the form of 'have' or 'get'.
academic year
[k]I had my nails done[/k]
language programme
The meaning of 'have something done' and 'get something done' are very similar. Using 'have' is often a bit more formal.
Tonight I have guests for dinner.
[k]I do the gardening[/k]
